title: Howqua River
text:
The Howqua River, a minor inland <a href="perennial%20river">perennial river</a> of the <a href="Goulburn%20River">Goulburn</a> <a href="Broken%20River%20%28Victoria%29">Broken</a> catchment, part of the <a href="Murray-Darling%20basin">Murray-Darling basin</a>, is located in the <a href="Victorian%20Alps">alpine</a> region of the <a href="Australia">Australia</a>n state of <a href="Victoria%20%28Australia%29">Victoria</a>. The headwaters of the Howqua River rise below <a href="Mount%20Howitt">Mount Howitt</a> in the western slopes of the <a href="Victorian%20Alps">Victorian Alps</a>, and descend to flow into the <a href="Goulburn%20River">Goulburn River</a> within <a href="Lake%20Eildon">Lake Eildon</a>.
Location and features.
The river rises below Mount Howitt on the western slopes of the Victorian Alps, within the <a href="Alpine%20National%20Park">Alpine National Park</a> in the <a href="Shire%20of%20Mansfield">Shire of Mansfield</a>. The river flow generally west, joined by five minor tributaries, before reaching its <a href="confluence">confluence</a> with the Goulburn River within Lake Eildon, created by the Eildon Weir. The river descends over its <a href="watercourse">course</a>.
Cultural references.
The Howqua valley was seasonally occupied by the <a href="Taungurong">Taungurong</a> people with the valley being a major route for trade or war between tribes in the area. The Howqua River valley contains a number of archaeological sites of significance including at least two quarry sites for <a href="Greenschist">greenstone</a>, an exceptionally hard rock used for stone axes, spears and other cutting tools which the Taungurong traded with other tribes.
The character of Billy Slim in <a href="Nevil%20Shute">Nevil Shute</a>'s 1952 novel "<a href="The%20Far%20Country%20%281952%20novel%29">The Far Country</a>" was based on Fred Fry, a notable fly fisherman, who constructed several huts along the Howqua River and eked out a quiet existence in the river valley.
The Howqua River was one of just thirteen locations worldwide featured on the <a href="fly%20fishing">fly fishing</a> documentary television series "<a href="A%20River%20Somewhere">A River Somewhere</a>".
Etymology.
In the <a href="Australian%20Aboriginal%20languages">Aboriginal</a> <a href="Woiwurrung%20language">Woiwurrung</a> and <a href="Daungwurrung%20language">Daungwurrung</a> languages, the river is named Pyerlite, with no clearly defined meaning.
There are four possible origins of the river's current name: firstly, after John "Howka" Hunter (1820–68), a <a href="Pastoral%20farming">pastoralist</a>; secondly, a <a href="portmanteau">portmanteau</a> name from Mount Howitt, where the river rises, and "aqua"; thirdly, after Howqua, a popular brand of Chinese tea in the early nineteenth century; and fourthly, after Akin Howqua (Ah Kin Wowqua), a Chinese surveyor and early resident of Melbourne.
